title: France’s Macron Under Pressure as Recent Terrorist Attacks Weigh on Regional Elections
sub_head: Vote provides early window into how voters are responding to the violence ahead of next year’s presidential election
body:
PARIS—Millions of French voters headed to the polls on Sunday for regional elections in a country grappling with recent terrorist attacks and tensions over the place of Islam in society.
Conservative candidates campaigning on anti-immigration and law-and-order pledges jumped out to a significant lead in the first round of voting a week ago, piling pressure on the centrist party of President Emmanuel Macron, who faces re-election next year.
Conservatives garnered an estimated 29.3% of the vote nationally last Sunday amid record-high abstention rates, while Marine Le Pen’s antimigrant National Rally took a lower-than-expected 19.1%. The Socialist Party and the Green Party won 16.5% and 13.2% respectively, while Mr. Macron’s party came in fifth with 10.9%.
On Sunday, turnout by midday was 12.66%, slightly up from last week’s record low of 12.22%, according to the French Interior Ministry. Turnout stood at 19.59% at the same time in the previous regional elections in 2015.
France has been buffeted by a string of terrorist attacks in recent years, including the beheading of a middle-school teacher by a Chechen refugee in October. That attack stunned the nation, with Mr. Macron describing it as an assault on France’s Enlightenment values and cracking down on mosques across the country.
